required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Quantitative Study of Prevalence and Vulnerability Factors of Active Cyber Sexuality Among Teenagers in West Normandy
clinical_study.official_title: Prevalence and Vulnerability Factors of Active Cybersexuality Among Teenagers (15 - 17 Olds) in West Normandy.

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates prevalence of active cybersexuality among teenagers (15-17 old) in West Normandy and find different factors of vulnerability that could induce this behaviour. Selection of teenagers in different schools (general, professional, agricultural, reintegration structure).

detailed_description.textblock: the teen completes a questionnaire at the beginning of sexual education session. This questionnaire put in an anonymous box. After, there is a debate on the subject with the speaker, teenager ask questions about sexuality.

primary_outcome.description: if teenagers send, receive or forward pictures or videos nude, use dedipix, participate to skin party, speak on chats. Evaluation by anonymous questionnaire distributed at the beginning of the session. They answered "yes" or "no" or "I don't want to answer" . If They answered "yes" to one question they were considered to be practicing cybersexuality

secondary_outcome.measure: factors of vulnerability that induce sexuality on the internet
secondary_outcome.description: factors of vulnerability are: gender, welfare, emotional bond with parents, accessibility of internet, use internet and social network, see pornography, addictive behavior, trauma in the past. Evaluation by anonymous questionnaire. Inside, Using an analog scale for the consumption of the internet and phone, more the number is important (the max was 10 hours and 200 sms) more the teenagers surfed in the internet. For the others questions , four answers are possible "yes very well", "yes, well", "not really" "not at all" more they answered not at all more it was a factor of vulnerability

arm_group.description: this group of teenagers use internet for sexuality

arm_group.arm_group_label: not sexual behavior on the internet
arm_group.description: this group of teenagers doesn't use internet for sexuality

study_pop.textblock: population of teenagers of different school structures . make differences between the urban schools and the rural schools

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- all of teenagers participate a sexual education session
Exclusion Criteria:
- <15 old and 18 old and more
- the school doesn't want to participate
- one parent refuses that his adolescent participate. If requested exclusion, the group to which belongs the child is excluded
- teenager refuses to participate

reference.citation: Braun-Courville DK, Rojas M. Exposure to sexually explicit Web sites and adolescent sexual attitudes and behaviors. J Adolesc Health. 2009 Aug;45(2):156-62. doi: 10.1016/j.jadohealth.2008.12.004. Epub 2009 Feb 20.
